label: Global
notes: Curated market signals used to add context on the results page. Not exhaustive, and not a substitute for local job research.

trendingRoles.title: AI Implementation Specialist
trendingRoles.why: Translates business problems into practical AI + automation workflows; high demand across industries.

trendingRoles.title: AI Enablement Specialist
trendingRoles.why: Drives safe adoption via training, SOPs, and internal playbooks.

trendingRoles.title: Agent Orchestrator (AI Ops)
trendingRoles.why: Runs and monitors agentic workflows with guardrails and QA.

trendingRoles.title: Automation Analyst (Ops / RevOps)
trendingRoles.why: Eliminates repetitive business work via automations, dashboards, and documentation.

trendingRoles.title: Data Steward / Data Quality
trendingRoles.why: AI systems depend on clean, governed data; data quality roles are expanding.

trendingRoles.title: AI Governance / Responsible AI
trendingRoles.why: Policy, compliance, and auditability needs rise with AI adoption.

trendingRoles.title: AI Platform / MLOps Engineer
trendingRoles.why: Production reliability and deployment at scale are bottlenecks as AI moves into core systems.

trendingRoles.title: AI Production Strategist (Creative Ops)
trendingRoles.why: Builds brand-safe AI creative workflows; combines tooling, taste, QA, and process.

recurringSkillSignals.why: Organizations need repeatability, not one-off prompting.
Most automation and AI projects become data plumbing problems quickly.
AI outputs must be judged, verified, and monitored.
Turning ambiguity into executable workflows is a core differentiator.
Safe usage and data handling are becoming baseline requirements.
Teams want outcomes across tools; integrations create leverage.
